results.title: Science: keeping you in the picture
results.creator_credit: Mark Laughlin, Gil Davidson and Victoria. Education Dept. Curriculum Branch
results.brief_description: Trevor Lunn introduces Janet Hollands and Mark learmonth who provide an explanation of the process by which films and videos for science teachers were selected for inclusion in the Victorian Education Department’s Film and Video Collection. Includes excerpts from titles held in the collection.

results.title: Science of milk production
results.brief_description: Made under the supervision of Prof. W. E. Peterson, internationally recognized dairying expert, this film condenses a vast amount of scientific data into a simple and easily understood account of how the cow functions as a milk factory. The productive life of a cow can be considered in four period: (1) dry cow; (2) calf; (3) growing heifer; (4) milk cow. Through the use of animated diagrams and actual laboratory experiments carried out at the University of Minnesota, USA, the functioning of the cow’s digestive and milk-producing organs are demonstrated. The importance of proper diet for the cow, and the correct use of the milking machine (as well as the results of incorrect use) are demonstrated, and the film points out the factors which can be made to contribute to a plentiful, high quality milk yield.

results.title: Science in the orchestra
results.creator_credit: Alex Strasser, Brian Smith, Dorothy Grayson, Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group and Realist Films
results.brief_description: An exposition of the physics of orchestral sound for young people and adults. Conductor Muir Mathieson of the London Symphony Orchestra, and a physics demonstrator reveal facts about sound which fall into three sections, namely, 1. hearing the orchestra; 2. exploring the instruments; 3. looking at sounds.

results.title: Science goes wool-growing
results.creator_credit: Roland Litchfield, Cinesound, Litchfield TV and Pagewood Studios
results.brief_description: Deals with the use of chemicals and fertilisers in sheep raising. Opening with shots of the Commonwealth Fertilisers and Chemicals Ltd factory at Yarraville, Victoria, shows the manufacture of super-phosphate and other agricultural products. Reviews research and experimental work associated with the development of new materials. Describes ways in which graziers can achieve maximum benefit from chemicals and fertilisers.

results.title: Science goes fishing
results.brief_description: Scientists from Laval University and the Federal Fisheries Research Board carry on scientific research in Gaspe to improve cod-fishing. The film tells how much time and patience were needed before the fishing folk of the area would accept scientific methods of fishing.

results.title: Science for the tropics
results.creator_credit: Tony Baker, Richard Tamblind and Technical and Scientific Films
results.brief_description: A look at the work of the Tropical Products Institute in London, an organisation which assists third world countries to exploit their natural resources commercially. The Institute also does much laboratory work relating to agricultural issues. The film contains quite technical examinations of several projects the Institute has been involved in.

results.title: Science for the space age: waves and energy
results.creator_credit: Stanley Croner, Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explains that there are many kinds of waves, including water, sound, light and radio waves. Uses illustrations and experiments to show how waves carry energy from one place to another. Describes the relationship between frequency and wave length; and explains how radio waves carry information.

results.title: Science fiction: towards the twentieth century
results.creator_credit: Roger Thompson, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Explores the ways in which the social and technological changes of the 19th century led writers to think of the future world as a very different world from the present. Shows the themes which pre-occupied Victorians were taken up by writers of predicive fiction and projected into the 20th century and beyond. Shows excerpts from “Things to come” and book illustrations from “War of the worlds” and “Time machine”. Presented by Simon Eliot. Novel excerpts read by Patrick Troughton. Suitable for secondary level.
